channel.title: Comments on: JavaScript File & Folder Structures: Just Pick One

item.title: By: Ryan Johnston
item.dc:creator: Ryan Johnston
item.description:
Completely agree with your opinion Derick especially in a practical matter.
I found working with RequireJS if I used a type based folder structure when it came to optimization RequireJS would have issues as "person.js" (model) and "person.js" (collection) cause name spacing issues if you were trying to build one module unless you hard coded the name in the define method which defeats it's purpose.
item.content:encoded:
Completely agree with your opinion Derick especially in a practical matter.

I found working with RequireJS if I used a type based folder structure when it came to optimization RequireJS would have issues as “person.js” (model) and “person.js” (collection) cause name spacing issues if you were trying to build one module unless you hard coded the name in the define method which defeats it’s purpose.

item.title: By: Anonymous
item.dc:creator: Anonymous
item.description: Good stuff Derick. Organization with JS is tough sometimes, but then I take a deep breath and realize, it doesn't REALLY matter all that much as long as I and the members of my team all have a good understanding about how our app works!
item.content:encoded: Good stuff Derick. Organization with JS is tough sometimes, but then I take a deep breath and realize, it doesn’t REALLY matter all that much as long as I and the members of my team all have a good understanding about how our app works!

item.title: By: Tim Branyen
item.dc:creator: Tim Branyen
item.description: Completely agree about organizing code around the type of Class it is. Lumping dozens of Models into a single folder just seems like a completely awful way of structuring your code.
item.content:encoded: Completely agree about organizing code around the type of Class it is.  Lumping dozens of Models into a single folder just seems like a completely awful way of structuring your code.
